@SimonJGuilfoyle As thought experiment you could think about how to control banks w/out numerical targets. Solve that & I can make you rich.
@SimonJGuilfoyle I'm testing the limits of that really. I don't subscribe to all numerical targets bad quite yet.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Haha well I can usually be relied on for a debate. Tbh, I've argued one way, but my sympathy is with your side.
@SimonJGuilfoyle I'll certainly enjoy reading that! May take me back a few years to my own war stories.
@SimonJGuilfoyle all available evidence in the cool light of day, and stick to it in the heat of the moment.
@SimonJGuilfoyle That's a brilliant question. Is it ever? I suppose my point is that maybe in some cases yrs. Choose your target with 1/2
@SimonJGuilfoyle Agreed. It's a huge problem. But as I've repeatedly said I'm not a target cheerleader.
@SimonJGuilfoyle That isn't to say that I agree with all targets in old manufacturing. Most are stupid obviously.
@SimonJGuilfoyle But push too hard and risks disaster. Hence targets.
@SimonJGuilfoyle No-one has a clue about ultimate capability of large, complex plants like that. Only find by doing.
@SimonJGuilfoyle No! Operating parameters never fully known. Too complex.
@SimonJGuilfoyle I don't think so? My point is that numerical target in this case guides learning within (supposedly) safe parameters.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Yep but I think only can work if params are known, which wouldn't always be?
@SimonJGuilfoyle So set targets got yield / gauge at various points. Still a numeric target, and risks up other targets somewhat.
@SimonJGuilfoyle But manufacturing accuracy is within that tolerance. At least in the West. But accuracy worst towards start point.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Maybe easier example is the gauge target. All steel products have a tolerance right?
@SimonJGuilfoyle The target is the result of the learning. It allows people to aim for something that others have already learned.
@SimonJGuilfoyle In practice you need to control the variables you can and the targets help with the to a degree. Not most important factor.
@SimonJGuilfoyle In some regards I'd like to agree with you. Why have a target when you can just optimise everything, & get the best output.
@SimonJGuilfoyle We'll agree to disagree.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Show you where to allocate resources, and stop people 'improving' too much. As there are implications to that.
@SimonJGuilfoyle work to improve productivity and yield goes on. The targets tend to even consistently across variables (shots, products).
@SimonJGuilfoyle I think your view may be influenced by having seen targets as the endgame. In mill would be a holding pattern while the 1/2
@SimonJGuilfoyle I'm familiar with LD but IME you'll often have to make assumptions and targets are just that.
@SimonJGuilfoyle All rolling mills n the world have yield targets. Are they all wrong?
@SimonJGuilfoyle Don't. I'm not a cheerleader for binary pass / fail. It puts a break on success.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Good point, but thats not great for initial design work I think.

@SimonJGuilfoyle Or a yield ratio in a rolling mill?
Or a target weight for a team designing a new component?
@SimonJGuilfoyle For example: banks tier 1 cap ratio. You'd say don't have a numeric target for that? Or a retirement fund?
@SimonJGuilfoyle On the context. Where success can only be measured in numbers and there are skewed or binary outcomes possible from results
@SimonJGuilfoyle That wasn't what I was saying. I meant as per the stuff in the previous conversation.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Thanks again.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Yes, I will have a look at the above. Though I get the impression I'm already aligned with it. As per my previous.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Careful application is different to don't ever consider. That's where I'd need to be convinced.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Among that, where should I start for 'never do numeric targets'? As that's what I want to go at.
@SimonJGuilfoyle Hi Simon. Thanks for all that, that's great. I'm negative on that stuff myself, but that was not really my point.

@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Yes, but if you're reaching for a particular outcome, then target and reality are somewhat indivisible?
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Yes, that's a good point. I can't game my own target really.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Indeed. More importantly it forces me to confront reality. Which is the +ve aspect of any target IMV.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Yep, I have 4 targets for that. But also targets on per-cent of total income invested, etc.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx No, not like that. I'm an investor, not a trader so no short term time targets.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx But I'll also look at risk measures and stuff. If points are breeched, then strat is not working, etc.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Quite complex. I have a size targets for funds. if I'm behind then I'll divert more to some. 1/2.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx But even though I think that targets are bad, I feel the need to set them for myself; rarely for others

@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx 
My investment funds
My (own) company's performance
My kids' school grades
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Well again, I think I'd mostly agree. But then I set targets for my own life, so I'm a hypocrite.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx well I think my point is that the culture eventually replaces the target, not is built on.

@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx But the successful ones it becomes culture, so the target is arbitrary anyhow.  
So we sort of agree.

@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx 3M has benefited (xx % of rev from products created in last 3 yrs)
There are plenty tbh.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx resources, so you will revert, game, etc. But if after meeting target, can build-into culture..?
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx I sort of agree, but am not as negative on that as you I think. Prob w/ targets is that they divert 1/2

@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx I have mixed feelings on that. I've seen evidence both ways. 
Depends on the organisation I think.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Again agree, though if can embed the behaviour that got your boost into process and culture: is perm
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Funnily enough the example I had in mind was to drive transformation - provide a short term boost.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx I agree up to a point. Culture is what counts long-term, in which case targets meaningless.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx The example I had in mind is a bit involved for 140 chars

@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Tier-1 capital ratio at an investment bank for example. 
Not a great example, but you get the point.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx By forcing attention / behaviour / resources toward one side of the outcome, which may avoid doom.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx I agree. I'd tend to avoid targets unless there are binary outcomes / existential threats, etc.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx outcome either side of the target. Had that situation myself recently.
@AngryofAlton @SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Because the only way of measuring success in some areas is numeric, and you may have a binary 1/2
@SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Having said all that, if there is any evidence to back up num target = bad, I'd be interested in reading it.
@SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx For me, saying numerical targets = bad is just as faulty as applying numerical targets inappropriately. Sorry.
@SimonJGuilfoyle @tedx Some numerical targets are fine, and to be honest I'd go so far as to say unavoidable.
@SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx Numerical targets *can* cause dysfunctional behaviour, not must. But so can *any* measurable target.
@SimonJGuilfoyle @TEDx OK, I'm glad we agree that's not what your papers show, but again I think you've leapt to a flawed conclusion.
